skill.name: semantic-code-hunter
skill.description: Use when you need to find code by concept (not just text). Uses Serena MCP for semantic code search across the codebase with minimal token usage. Ideal for understanding architecture, finding authentication flows, or multi-file refactoring.
skill.summary: Use when you need to find code by concept (not just text). Uses Serena MCP for semantic code search ...
skill.author: Barnhardt-Enterprises-Inc

security_audit.summary: Pure documentation skill with no executable code. All 28 static findings are false positives: backticks in Markdown are code formatting syntax, not shell execution; source URL is metadata; hash strings and text descriptions contain no cryptographic code or C2 indicators.

content.user_title: Find code by concept with semantic search
content.value_statement: Finding code by exact text match misses related concepts and requires reading many files. This skill uses Serena MCP semantic search to find code by meaning, reducing token usage by 93 percent while finding more relevant results across your codebase.
actual_capabilities: Find symbols by concept instead of exact name match
Trace code relationships and dependencies across files
Get file structure overview without loading full content
Search for authentication, validation, and business logic patterns
Locate all usages of a function, class, or interface
Map complete code flows across multiple files
limitations: Requires Serena MCP server to be running and indexed
Not suitable for simple text searches or very small projects
Cannot edit or modify code directly
Requires understanding of semantic search concepts

best_practices: Start with broad search terms and narrow down with type filters
Combine semantic search with grep for text matches and read for details
Use find_referencing_symbols to understand impact before making changes
anti_patterns: Using semantic search for simple text replacements
Skipping the overview step and jumping directly to specific symbols
Not re-indexing after adding new files to the project

faq.question: What is the difference between semantic search and grep?
faq.answer: Grep finds exact text matches. Semantic search finds code by meaning and concept, discovering related symbols even with different names.

faq.question: How much token savings does this provide?
faq.answer: Semantic search typically uses 93 percent fewer tokens compared to reading entire files and manual analysis.

faq.question: Does this work with all programming languages?
faq.answer: Serena MCP supports major languages including JavaScript, TypeScript, Python, Java, Go, and Rust with more being added.

faq.question: Is my code data sent to external servers?
faq.answer: The skill is purely instructional. Code handling depends on Serena MCP configuration which runs locally or with your chosen provider.

faq.question: Why are no results returned for my search?
faq.answer: Check spelling, try broader terms, or re-index your project. Serena may need the project indexed first with serena project index.

faq.question: When should I use this instead of regular search?
faq.answer: Use semantic search for understanding architecture, finding concepts, and multi-file refactoring. Use grep for simple text matches in small projects.
